pages.text: The $(item)Solar Compressor/$ generates $(l:base_concepts/pressure)compressed air/$ and $(l:base_concepts/heat)heat/$ from $(thing)sunlight/$. To function, it requires a clear view of direct sunlight. This means it is unable to function inside, during the night, or during storms.

While the $(item)Solar Compressor/$ generates compressed air, it also generates heat proportional to how much compressed air is generated. Proper heat management is necessary to reach the full potential of the $(item)Solar Compressor/$: too little heat and the compressor will barely generate any compressed air, too much heat and the compressor with overheat and breakdown, requiring manual repairs with $(l:components/solar_cell)Solar Cells/$.

$(l:machines/heat_sink)Heat Sinks/$, $(l:machines/heat_pipe)Heat Pipes/$, and $(l:tubes/air_grate_module)Air Grates Modules/$ are the best tools to manage and remove the heat generated by the $(item)Solar Compressor/$. $(l:machines/vortex_tube)Vortex Tubes/$ are also useful for heat management, as they can be used to generate additional heat to reach max efficiency. With the right setup, even $(l:base_concepts/upgrades#speed)max speed/$ $(item)Solar Compressors/$ can reach a heat equilibrium at max efficiency.

The compressor has built-in thermal padding that activates whenever it is unable to generate compressed air, preventing it from gaining or losing any heat while inactive.$(br2)The compressor reaches max efficiency at $(thing)350°C/$, and overheats at $(thing)425°C/$.
